xml:
DISODIUM HYDROGEN CITRATE WITH GLUCOSE, POTASSIUM CHLORIDE AND SODIUM CHLORIDE Oral rehydration salts

Formulated as oral rehydration salts

Indications and dose

Fluid and electrolyte loss in diarrhoea

By mouth

  • Child 1–11 months

    1–1½ times usual feed volume to be given.

  • Child 1–11 years

    200 mL, to be given after every loose motion.

  • Child 12–17 years

    200–400 mL, to be given after every loose motion, dose according to fluid loss.

  • Adult

    200–400 mL, to be given after every loose motion, dose according to fluid loss.

 Directions for administration

Reconstitute 1 sachet with 200mL of water (freshly boiled and cooled for infants); 5 sachets reconstituted with 1 litre of water provide Na+ 60 mmol, K+ 20 mmol, Cl– 60 mmol, citrate 10 mmol, and glucose 90 mmol.
Prescribing and dispensing information

Flavours of oral powder formulations may include black currant, citrus, or natural.
Patient and carer advice

In children

Medicines for Children leaflet: Oral rehydration salts

www.medicinesforchildren.org.uk/oral-rehydration-salts

After reconstitution any unused solution should be discarded no later than 1 hour after preparation unless stored in a refrigerator when it may be kept for up to 24 hours.
Medicinal forms

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.
